item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: ackerman
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Umarex Legends C96
item.dc:creator: staff
item.content:encoded: Umarex introduces a few new products at the SHOT Show 2014. The Legends C96 is a broom-handle replica. It has a 19-round drop free magazine that provides a realistic feel with a dash of nostalgia. Another new offering from Umarex is the Makarov Ultra. It has a blow-back slide action, and is a great option for backyard plinking. For more information, visit Umarex.com.

item.title: Umarex Colt 1911 WWII Commemorative Edition
item.dc:creator: staff
item.content:encoded: Umarex is offering a special edition commemorative WWII 1911 only at SHOT Show 2014. Dealers will be ordering some of the 500 that are being produced to be sold near you. This 1911 airgun features an aged finish, grips and barrel. For more information, visit Umarex.com.
item.excerpt:encoded: Umarex is offering a special edition commemorative WWII 1911 only at SHOT Show 2014 that dealers are buying to resell in stores near you!

item.title: Redfield Battlezone 6-18x44 mm
item.dc:creator: staff
item.content:encoded: Mark Keefe talks with John Stodgrass from Redfield, owned by Leupold, about the companies latest optic, the Battlezone 6-18x44 mm. This optic has a .223/5.56 mm NATO dial set up for 55-grain bullets at 3,100 fps, and the second dial has a .308/7.62 mm NATO dial for 168-grain bullets at 2,650 fps. Each dial is marked in 50-yard increments. The scope features fully multicoated lenses, BDC system and a TAC-MOA reticle. Other features include fully waterproof nitrogen-filled main tubes to prevent fogging and freezing and a lifetime warranty. For more information, visit Redfield.com.
item.excerpt:encoded: Mark Keefe talks with John Stodgrass from Redfield, owned by Leupold, about the companies latest optic, the Battlezone 6-18x44 mm.

item.title: Pre-Season Patterning Part 2: Turkey Guns
item.dc:creator: John Zent
item.content:encoded:
Because pattern effectiveness of turkey guns changes markedly from close (say, 15 yards) to long range (40+ yards), smart hunters know they must pattern at multiple distances.
While virtually all turkey loads from 12- or 20-gauge guns will absolutely KO a turkey at close range, patterns from specialized extra-full-choked guns may be no wider than a softball at 12 or 15 yards. That means it’s not all that difficult to miss if you’re not aware of the downrange spread and need for careful shooting technique.
I start my due diligence at 15 yards, and in just 2 or 3 shots I know if I’m off even by a little. These days I’m using red-dot or reflex sights, so if needed I adjust windage to be dead-on and elevation so that roughly 60 percent of the pattern is higher than my point of aim. That way I’m allowing for drop at long range, and while drop is marginal at most effective pattern distances, I want every edge I can get out at shoot/don’t shoot yardages.
After dialing in at 15, I move on to 30 yards. Normally it’s not necessary to readjust the sight, but nonetheless it’s helpful to see mid-range patterns. After that, it’s all about determining maximum effective range based on pattern density. I’ll keep extending until the pattern gets too ‘loose’, then it’s time to reel the board back in a few yards. For me, the go/no-go point is 30 hits in a 10” circle--roughly the length of a tom’s head and neck—providing the pellets are evenly distributed.
It can take as many as five or six shots to dial in a red-dot or scope sight, and then a couple more shots at each distance to make the necessary observations, and so turkey hunter patterning takes some work and can run through a dozen or more shells. You can also eat through numerous targets and considerable time running them out, so I like to set up multiples at each distance. Fortunately turkey patterns can be shot on standard 8-1/2”x11” paper, and you can opt for printed targets showing the bird’s internal spine/brain anatomy, or save a few bucks and make your own on printer or notebook paper. I find it easy simply to staple targets to cardboard boxes, and then trash the lot of it when I’m done.
Mostly the shooting is done from a bench in order to get the steadiest results, as when sighting-in a rifle. However, I like to shoot from the knees-up sitting position that simulates actual hunting. That way I can steady the gun, get realistic practice, and don’t take quite the beating from recoil. Commercial turkey loads can really hammer a shooter, so you will want to get ‘er done as efficiently as possible. Nevertheless don’t be tempted to shirk this important preparation. You won’t be sorry when big boy is floppin’ out there in the spring woods.
item.excerpt:encoded: Pattern testing your shotgun is a key element to preparation for turkey season.

item.title: Tune Your M1 Garand Or M1A Rifle With This Drop-In
item.dc:creator: BrianSheetz
item.content:encoded: Firing M1 Garand or M1A rifles with loads carrying bullets heavier than those designed for the guns can be hard on them and could lead to damage to the guns' operating rods. Even some standard loads can cause premature wear and unnecessarily robust ejection. The Adjustable M1 Garand Gas System and Adjustable M1A Gas Plug from Schuster Mfg., Inc. (schustermfg.com) addresses both concerns by allowing the user to control the volume of gas contained by the gas cylinder, altering the velocity of the operating rod and allowing even single-shot firing. Both units, which are machined in the United States from hardened tool steel and Parkerized, simply replace the guns’ standard gas system plugs, requiring no permanent modification to the rifles and are legal for CMP Service Rifle competition. An included Allen wrench facilitates adjustment of the system and tightens a jam nut to lock adjustments once they are determined. If this isn't an easy Gun DIY, I don't know what is. Have you tried it?
item.excerpt:encoded: Firing M1 Garand or M1A rifles with loads carrying bullets heavier than those designed for the guns can be hard on them and could lead to damage to the guns' operating rods.

item.title: Nikon's Rock Your Rimfire Promotion is Back
item.dc:creator: staff
item.content:encoded: Until May 11, 2014, firearms enthusiasts can save up to $40 on select models of Nikon's rimfire-dedicated riflescopes, all of which are compatible with Nikon's Spot On Custom Turrets. "Year after year our Rock Your Rimfire promotion continues to be a favorite," said Nikon General Manager Jon Allen. "We hope shooters will take advantage of these savings and make the most of their .22 ammunition with one of our rimfire-specific optics." The promotion includes the following models of Nikon rimfire dedicated riflescopes: • 4x32 PROSTAFF Rimfire Nikoplex • 3-9x40 PROSTAFF Rimfire BDC 150 • 3-9x40 AO PROSTAFF Target EFR • 2-7x32 P22 Nikoplex • 2-7x32 P22 BDC 150 • 2-7x32 P-Rimfire Nikoplex • 2-7x32 P-Rimfire BDC 150 For terms and conditions of the Rock Your Rimfire promotion, go to Nikonpromo.com.

item.title: So What The Heck Is A Screw Gizzie Anyway?
item.dc:creator: BrianSheetz
item.content:encoded: If you’ve ever tried to shorten a small screw by holding it against a motorized grinding wheel, then you know that it can not only be frustrating but downright dangerous. The screw tends to heat up quickly, burning your thumb and fingers, and it inevitably gets caught by the fast-spinning wheel and shot across the shop at high speed. At best you can get down on hands and knees and find it, only to start the process over, and at worst you can sustain an eye injury (that is if you weren’t wearing goggles, which you should be if you’re working on a grinder). Enter Brownell’s Screw Gizzie (Part # 080-554-000AE). It’s a simple affair involving two 2 3/8”-long by 3/8”-wide pieces of spring steel held together at one end by a rivet. At the other end of each piece is a hole. Just pry or fan the pieces apart enough to slip a screw into one of the holes in such a way that its head rests between them and the threaded portion protrudes through the similar-size hole. Now you can hold the Gizzie itself at the rivet end while allowing it to press the screw’s threaded end against the grinding wheel with no chance of getting your fingers overheated or having the screw snatched away. A side benefit is that the screw tends to rotate in the Gizzie as its end is being ground smooth, making the finished surface appear as though it was turned on a lathe.
item.excerpt:encoded: If you’ve ever tried to shorten a small screw by holding it against a motorized grinding wheel, then you know that it can not only be frustrating but downright dangerous.

item.title: Alpine Innovations Spuds Pro
item.dc:creator: prackley
item.content:encoded: There are few irritations that compare with realizing that optics are covered with rain, mud dirt or smudges when needed. You could be close to an once-in-a-lifetime shot and the only thing you have to clean your scope is a handkerchief or shirt tail because your cleaning kit is back at camp. That’s when a compact scope-cleaning kit in the pocket or pack would come in very handy. The Spuds Pro from Alpine Innovations is a compact made-in-the-USA cleaning kit that comes with streak-free cleaning solution and a scratch-less micro-fleece cloth for making the glass on a scope, camera or binocular shine for clear viewing. It’s small enough to be carried in the pocket and it comes in a small bag that has a clip for attaching to a belt loop, pack or even a rifle sling, so it is always at hand. At only $11, it is also affordable enough to keep multiples around for a variety of jobs, such as cleaning eyeglasses, music CDs and portable electronics. I’ve used mine to clean every riflescope I own, as well to stop a DVD from skipping in the player.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Spuds Pro can be used to clean a variety of delicate products, such as the glass on riflescopes and binoculars, as well as electronics and DVDs.

item.title: More Women with Guns
item.dc:creator: prackley
item.content:encoded: Reports from the National Shooting Sports Foundation show that more and more women are becoming involved in the shooting sports, with one in four women now owning a gun. That is a 77 percent increase since 2005. There is a lot of discussion on both sides of the firearm debate on the whys of this trend, but it definitely seems like more women want the ability to protect themselves and their family. While this is a good thing, I can’t help but wonder where these women are receiving the necessary training to be safe and effective in firearms use. I hope it’s not from their significant others. It has been my experience that husbands and wives and boyfriends and girlfriends don’t do well in a teaching environment. Sure, it is OK for a man to take his wife or girlfriend to the range for a “get acquainted” session with firearms and safety is crucial to that end, but real training should come from someone who isn’t emotionally involved in the situation for many reasons. One, most people benefit from the knowledge and experience of a certified instructor. Two, too many men want to push women toward what they have decided is the best gun or method. There are countless stories of guys handing a compact 1911 or snubnosed .357 to his significant other to help them “understand” what is needed. In those cases, I truly understand why some women never become interested in shooting. Thankfully, a lot of guys are beginning to understand that this is not beneficial when introducing newcomers to the joys of firearms. Finally, it is just more difficult to learn from someone who has a vested interest in the person learning about guns. I am a NRA Certified Handgun and Personal Protection in the Home Instructor, and while I have the experience and knowledge to teach my wife about shooting—I took her shooting a few times and taught her the basics of safety and handling—she still took a basic handgun class. I will also start my kids on shooting, but will require that they receive training from other instructors. Beyond the vested interest that may make me push a little hard, I also feel that it is good for them to learn from others who have different methods and styles. I have received countless training over the years and spend a great deal of time developing my skills. However, I love attending firearm classes, as I can always learn more.
item.excerpt:encoded: As more women obtain firearms for both enjoyment and defense, training becomes important and it is often best to learn from someone without a vested interest.

item.title: NRA Sports Youth Day is Fun for Kids
item.dc:creator: WendyLaFever
item.content:encoded: NRA Youth Programs, together with participating shooting-sports organizations like the Boy Scouts of America, Venturing, the National High School Rodeo Association and Royal Rangers hosted the NRA Sports Youth Day on Sunday of the NRA Annual Meetings. "It's a fun, activity-based experience for kids to come and participate, while they learn more about the shooting sports," said Claudia Olsen, NRA Youth Programs manager. Kids up to 18 years old, along with their parents or chaperons, were invited to attend this annual free event. A broad array of kid-friendly activities were on offer: an Airsoft 3-Gun challenge; face painting; wildlife identification challenge; cattle-roping tutorials courtesy of the National High School Rodeo Association (with a dummy "cow," naturally); and more. There were even surprise celebrity appearances, like from Season Four Top Shot winner Chris Cheng. The championship shooter "is just helping out with whatever the kids need," reported Olsen. There were also a wide variety of door prizes for the kids to win, donated by the generous sponsors (Brownells, Crosman, Marlin, Remington, Smith & Wesson, Sure-Shot, Winchester, Weatherby and Boyt). Participants picked up their "Indy Sponsor's Cruise Pit Card," named in honor of the host city of Indianapolis, labeled with each sponsor's name. The young attendees could then visit each sponsor's booth in the exhibition hall floor. As they checked off each location, they gathered fun free giveaways like t-shirts, duck calls, pins and more. "We may wind up with more than 1,000 kids enjoying these activities this year," Olsen continued. If you missed it, make plans now to bring your family for the 2015 NRA Annual Meetings & Exhibits in Nashville, Tenn.
item.excerpt:encoded: This free event for kids and parents is a yearly don't-miss.

item.title: History Lessons
item.dc:creator: sagi
item.content:encoded: Photo caption: Ukrainian citizens walk by another body in the street during the Stalin-enforced starvation known as the Holodomor. In the last few weeks, some frightening facts have slipped out of the Ukraine. Before you think I am jumping to conclusions, Hillary Clinton compared the Russian annexation of Crimea to Nazi aggression weeks ago. USA Today reported on April 17 that leaflets handed out to those of the Jewish faith in an occupied region of the Ukraine indicated they must “register” with the pro-Russian militants who seized control of the city.  The Washington Times and CNN carried similar stories. Then, on April 28—Israel’s official observation of Holocaust Remembrance Day—there was an assassination attempt on the Jewish mayor of Ukraine’s second-largest municipality. So far, there has been no link established to anti-Semitic groups. Unlike the 1938 German Weapons Act, Ukraine’s Jews apparently can have hunting long-arms. It requires a license (so the occupiers have a tidy list from which to work), self-defense isn’t a legitimate reason for ownership and it’s restrictive enough that on Feb. 20, the Ukrainian Gun Owners Association announced an effort, “….which will provide an unconditional right for Ukrainian citizens to bear arms.” The history of Russian treatment of Ukrainians nearly eclipses the Holocaust in terms of mortality. Joseph Stalin’s “Holodomor” starved to death somewhere between 2.4 and 7.5 million Ukrainians in 1932.
item.excerpt:encoded: Government-sanctioned prejudice can be deadly, especially when the victims cannot lawfully own guns for protection.
